title: 112_hr2872
content: The Act may be cited as the "Job Creation and Urban Revitalization Act of 2011" and includes a table of contents. The "Job Creation and Urban Revitalization Act of 2011" includes provisions for increased investment in job creating small businesses, updating definitions of low-income geographic areas, expanding operational assistance for small businesses in high unemployment areas, nationwide distribution of companies for new employment opportunities, and simplifying formulas for operational assistance grants. Authorization of appropriations for the New Markets Venture Capital Program is streamlined with a simplified application process. SEC. 2. INCREASED INVESTMENT IN JOB CREATING SMALL BUSINESS CONCERNS. Developmental Venture Capital and Participation Agreements in the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 are amended to encourage growth in small businesses located in high unemployment areas. The purposes include promoting economic development in low-income areas and creating job opportunities in high unemployment regions through developmental venture capital. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to promote growth in small businesses in high unemployment areas through developmental venture capital investments. This aims to stimulate economic development in low-income regions and create job opportunities in areas with high unemployment rates. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow investing in small businesses located in high unemployment areas, promoting economic development and job creation in those regions. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to require each conditionally approved company investing in small businesses in high unemployment areas to raise at least $3,000,000 of private capital from eligible investors. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include small business concerns in operational assistance grants. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to update the definition of low-income geographic areas and expand the uses for operational assistance for small business concerns in areas of high unemployment. Section 351 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to define "area of high unemployment" as a geographic area with an unemployment rate exceeding the national rate. Assistance is provided for small businesses in these areas to retool, update, or replace machinery and equipment to generate new employment opportunities nationwide. Section 354(c) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to promote nationwide investment by selecting companies from each geographic region of the Small Business Administration. Section 354(d) is amended to limit final approval time to 2 years. Matching requirements are eliminated for areas with high unemployment and designated urban manufacturing revitalization areas. Section 354(d)(2)(A)(i)(III) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to exclude companies primarily serving small businesses in high unemployment or urban manufacturing revitalization areas. Urban manufacturing revitalization areas are addressed in Section 9. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow the Administrator to designate urban manufacturing revitalization areas for small business investment. These areas must be low-income urban areas. The Administrator can designate urban manufacturing revitalization areas for small business investment in low-income urban areas. Priority is given to companies with a strong commitment to revitalizing urban areas through investment and assistance to small businesses. The Administrator will coordinate resources for small businesses served by approved companies. The Administrator designates procurement opportunities for small businesses in urban manufacturing revitalization areas through approved companies under the entrepreneurial development programs. Small business investment in urban areas is prioritized, with resources coordinated for small businesses served by approved companies. The Administrator requires small business concerns in urban manufacturing revitalization areas to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 in private capital from eligible investors. SEC. 10. Simplified formula for operational assistance grants amends section 358(a)(4) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The grant amount will be the lesser of 10 percent of resources raised by the company or $1,000,000. SEC. 11. Expands operational assistance to conditionally approved companies. Section 358(a) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow for grants to conditionally approved companies. The Administrator can grant funds to such companies, with repayment required if final approval is not received. The Administrator deducts grant amounts from subsequent grants for operational assistance if a company receives final approval. The maximum grant amount is $50,000. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 368(a) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. Changes include reducing the amount to $75,000,000 with at least 50 percent for companies in high unemployment areas, and decreasing the amount to $15,000,000 for other purposes. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, reducing the amount to $75,000,000 with at least 50 percent for companies in high unemployment areas. The Small Business Administration will create standard documents for a streamlined application process for New Markets Venture Capital companies, reducing costs.
